text: um the film is a documentary film called
the carrier and it takes place it was
shot in rural Zambia and it is about it
sort of surrounds itself around this
issue called prevention of
mother-to-child transmission or pmtct
and in that it focuses on the story of
this one woman who is HIV positive and
she's in she's a rural subsistence
farmer in a polygamous marriage where
three of the four adults are HIV
positive as well and she becomes
pregnant and so it's about what happens
in the course of her life in the
family's life as she's in this effort to
prevent the child from being born with
HIV well we're on the verge almost i
like to say of meaning we have the
resources and the tools to put to
potentially see an hiv-free generation
within the next 5 to 10 to 15 years sort
of depending on how much awareness is
raised and and and how much people can
gather around this issue and i think
that is an extraordinary thing I mean in
Africa in particular we've had like two
or three decades of this of this
pandemic just devastating this continent
and almost more on us and a sort of its
spiritual implications that you know
that that it gives people it makes
people feel like they're gaining ground
in this battle against this disease and
and the personal sense of of renewal and
hope that it can give to a mother as an
individual is amazing to me i was aware
that there was a 30-percent polygamy
rate in zambia but it never I had never
envisioned the story before we got there
and met this family that polygamy would
become a subject or topic in the film at
all and and I was very afraid of it you
know you have an idea in your head and I
was like I want to make a movie about a
woman trying to protect her baby and I
was very take on this whole situation
with this family in this polygamous
marriage it could become about something
else
the family themselves as individuals and
potential characters in a narrative were
so captivating and fascinating that we
were like well let's just go with it
we'll stay on topic but let's just sort
of see where it takes us
